sentence.text: A male infant born at 35 weeks of gestation to a 28-year-old gravida six and para four mother via elective Cesarean section.
He was the fourth child to consanguineous (first cousin) Lebanese parents (Figure 1).
Antenatal ultrasound scans showed bilateral humeral and femoral shortening with multiple fractures (Figure 2).

Late antenatal ultrasound at 34 weeks of gestation revealed congenital cardiac disease; severe tricuspid valve regurgitation, pulmonary valve regurgitation, dilatation of the right heart, cardiomegaly, and a small arterial duct.
The infant required intubation at birth with poor Apgar scores of 3 and 6 at 1 and 5 min, respectively.
Birthweight was 2.36 kg (24th centile).
At birth, severe limb deformity with contractures and skin tethering were noted, in addition to subtle facial dysmorphism (micrognathia, midface hypoplasia).
Radiographs (Figure 2) revealed multiple healing rib fractures, multiple healed limb fractures with flexion deformity of both elbows and knees.
Biochemistry was normal except for low levels of 25-hydroxy vitamin D at 15 nmol/L (≥50 nmol/L) managed with cholecalciferol supplementation.
Pamidronate (via central venous access) was given for management of perceived bone pain at 3 and 10 days of age, with a third dose planned but not administered due to the infant's death.
Postnatal echocardiogram (Figure 2) confirmed tricuspid valve dysplasia with valve prolapse and severe regurgitation.
The mitral valve was also abnormal with mild prolapse of the anterior leaflet and restriction of the posterior leaflet resulting in mild regurgitation.
There were small ductus arteriosus and elevated pulmonary pressures.
Cardiovascular therapy was directed at rapidly reducing the pulmonary vascular resistance to encourage antegrade flow through the right heart and reduce right ventricular afterload.
The infant was commenced on inhaled nitric oxide and sildenafil in addition to ongoing ventilation and oxygenation with some reduction in pulmonary pressures.
Cardiac prognosis was guarded and dependent on response to medical therapy.
Due to multiple factors cardiothoracic surgical intervention was not felt to be a viable option.
Invasive mechanical ventilation was commenced at birth and discontinued at 2 weeks of age with respiratory support weaned to high flow nasal canula oxygen.

He remained clinically stable for 2 weeks from a respiratory point of view but then deteriorated due to pulmonary hemorrhage requiring invasive mechanical ventilation to be recommenced with high ventilatory pressure and oxygen requirement.
Further deterioration occurred 1 week later with recurrent pulmonary hemorrhages and worsening oxygen desaturation despite maximal support.
